newsitem.title: MEXICO: ING Baring upgrades Mexico, cuts Venezuela.
newsitem.headline: ING Baring upgrades Mexico, cuts Venezuela.

text.p: ING Barings said Friday it has upgraded Mexico to modest overweight from underweight based on "the market's lagging year-to-date dollar performance" and other reasons.
At the same time, ING Barings said it was downgrading Venezuela to neutral from overweight because of lower dollar returns relative to those of Argentina, Brazil and Mexico.

The report, attributed to Tim Love, head of Latin American research, also upgraded Brazil's year-end stock exchange target to 12,100 points from 10,000 points "based on EPS revisions in the cyclical stocks", higher upsides on key stocks and positive developments on "reform bills and fiscal stability fund approval."
Brazil's Bovespa stock index was up 26 at 9,152 this morning.

The target for Peru's year-end stock index also was revised upward to 1,800 points from 1,700 points because "Mr. Love expects that Peru could see GDP recovery of 4.5 percent or more," adding that "consensus forecasts are rising to match those of ING Barings."
Peru's General Index was up 12.26 this morning at 1,662.73.

As for Mexico, the report said the upgrade was made in part because of "a perceived short-term peak in the widening of Mexican fixed-income spreads over U.S. Treasuries and a revised Mexican peso forecast."
ING Barings's year-end Mexican peso forecast has improved to 8.7 per dollar from 9.3 per dollar because of strong liquidity inflows and greater risk tolerance on the part of investors.

Venezuela's downgrade was due to reductions in oil prices and "a knock-on in market sentiment, as well as concerns over recent inflation data and its effect on either the currency or domestic EPS growth."
